   This is a 78 year-old male with a history of PEs, pulmonary
   hypertension, COP, chronic knee infection, afib/flutter and
   hypothyroidism who is transferred from [**Hospital1 7**] [**Location (un) 250**] with shock and acute
   renal failure.   Family meeting held to address goals of care
 goal to
   wean patient off pressors in order to transition him to home for
   hospice.  Hospice is being set up currently, family needs a day to get
   their home ready and then plan to d/c home tomorrow
   #  Goals of Care:  Family meeting held 3 days ago to discuss goals of
   care and prognosis.  Outcome of discussion is to attempt to wean
   patient off of pressors in effor to get him home for home hospice.
   Discussed medication regimen at length with team yesterdayand the
   following decisions were made:
   - continue sildenafil at 100mg tid to treat his RV failure, keep him
   off pressors and allow him to go home with hospice
   - will d/c iv antibiotics as has been no clear infection
   - continue one additional day of stress dose steroids, will then change
   to prednisone 10mg po qd
   - will continue po bactrim and augmentin for chronic osteomyelitis
   suppression
   - will d/c coumadin given patient was guaiac (+) as OSH given risk of
   bleed  - patient to see Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 206**] in 2 week and INR will be drawn
   then/determination whether or not to restart
   - Will not start Flolan as have been able to wean off pressor sand
   maintain blood pressures in 80
s just with sildenafil
   - PT consult to ensure that patient is able to stand and walk several
   steps as this goal is important for quality of life at home
   - palliative care following, appreciate recommendations - working to
   transition patient home to hospice.  Did not start Flolan as was able
   to wean off pressors and patient has remained cautiously stable for 24
   hours off pressor support.
   # Shock NOS:  Likely [**2-28**] to RV failure (chronic) and sub-optimally
   treated pulmonary hypertension as patient has not desired full
   treatment.  Patient with leukocytosis which is likely [**2-28**] to sstress
   dose steroids as not clinically systemically infected.  Currently off
   of neosynepherine.  Lasix challenge yesterday suggestive of slighty
   hypovolemia, also dropped pressures to 60's with AMS with fast
   recovery.  Patient with extremely poor forward flow and has little
   ability to maintain bp with changes in posture.
   - continue sildenafil 100mg tid
   - Flolan as above
   - abx d/c'ed as above
   - palliative care as above
   # Hyperkalemia: Resolved
   # ARF: Resolving
   - Continue to trend
   - Follow UOP with goal >30 and goal to fully wean pressors
   - Renally dose meds
   - Avoid nephrotoxins
   - has low Ca, will hold off on further work up given goal of care is
   for patient to go home
   # Cryptogenic organizing pna: Steroid dependent since [**Month (only) 1148**], has been
   unable to wean below 10 mg daily.  Patient was not clear on admission
   that this is the amount of prednisone he is actually taking daily.  On
   2L NC at night when at home.
   - steroids as above
   - continue po Bactrim for ppx
   - Continue supplemental oxygen as needed
   # Leukocytosis: Stable, likely  [**2-28**] steroids
   - trend
   # R TKR with chronic infection: Plain film showing free air within the
   joint space.  This is possible source of infection for septic shock.
   Has been on suppressive therapy with Augmentin and Bactrim, though
   wound is still poorly healing.
   - d/c abx as above
   - no further workup given goals of care
   # dCHF: Echo showed marked RV dysfunction with RV bowing into LV as
   above.  Prior echo in [**Month (only) 1148**] showed EF 65% with some old RV
   dysfunction, likely from prior PEs.  Also with pulmonary hypertension.
   - cautious fluid status managment as in very delicate balance
   # Multiple PEs: On coumadin, subtherapeutic, has h/o developing new PEs
   while on anticoagulation. Also has pulmonary hypertension [**2-28**] PEs, on
   viagra.
   - continue sildenafil 100mg tid
   - Heparin gtt given concern for PE
   # Anemia: 26 down from 33 two days ago. Possibly dilutional, no signs
   of bleeding though has guaiac pos stool in [**Location (un) 250**] ED.  Baseline Hct
   around 32 per report. Got 1 unit prbcs prior to transfer.
   - Guaiac all stools
   - Transfuse for <21
   # Afib/flutter:  Coumadin held last night at pt was supratherapeutic
   - coumadin as above
   - continue digoxin as keeping patient rate controlled important for
   maintenance of BP and quality of life
   - Continue to monitor on telemetry
   # ECG changes: He does have S1Q3T3, though not significantly changed
   from prior, patient has old RBBB. Troponin mildly elevated, and some ST
   depression in lateral precordial leads. No CP.
   - no active treatment
    # FEN: Regular diet as tolerated, encouraging po fliuds
   # Access: R femoral line, PIV

Based on the provided daily progress note, the patient is a 78-year-old male with a complex medical history, including pulmonary hypertension, chronic knee infection, afib/flutter, and hypothyroidism. He was transferred from another hospital with shock and acute renal failure. The patient's current condition is as follows:

1. Shock NOS: The patient's shock is likely related to right ventricular (RV) failure and sub-optimally treated pulmonary hypertension. He has been weaned off neosynepherine and is currently receiving sildenafil 100mg tid.
2. Renal Failure: The patient has acute renal failure, which is resolving. He will continue to trend and follow urine output (UOP) goals. Renally dose medications, and avoid nephrotoxins.
3. Hyperkalemia: This condition has been resolved.
4. Cryptogenic Organizing Pneumonia: The patient's condition is steroid-dependent, and he has been unable to wean off prednisone 10mg daily. He will continue to receive steroids and po Bactrim for prophylaxis.
5. Leukocytosis: The patient's leukocytosis is likely related to steroids and is stable. He will continue to trend.
6. R TKR with Chronic Infection: The patient has a chronic infection in his right knee replacement, which is a possible source of septic shock. He has been on suppressive therapy with Augmentin and Bactrim, but the wound is still poorly healing. The antibiotics have been discontinued.
7. dCHF: The patient has marked RV dysfunction with RV bowing into the left ventricle. He will require cautious fluid status management.
8. Multiple PEs: The patient has a history of pulmonary embolism (PE) and is on coumadin, which has been discontinued. He has also been prescribed heparin gtt to prevent further PEs.
9. Anemia: The patient's anemia is likely dilutional, and he will require transfusion if his hemoglobin level falls below 21.
10. Afib/flutter: The patient's atrial fibrillation (afib) is being managed with digoxin, and his rate is being controlled to maintain blood pressure and quality of life.
11. ECG Changes: The patient has S1Q3T3 on his ECG, which is not significantly changed from prior. He has old right bundle branch block (RBBB) and mild ST depression in lateral precordial leads.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Worsening renal failure: The patient's acute renal failure is resolving, but he may still require close monitoring and management to prevent further deterioration.
2. Infection: The patient's chronic infection in his right knee replacement and his history of PEs make him prone to further infections.
3. Cardiac complications: The patient's marked RV dysfunction and afib/flutter may lead to cardiac complications, such as heart failure or arrhythmias.
4. Bleeding: The patient's anemia and history of PEs make him at risk for bleeding.
5. Electrolyte imbalances: The patient's history of hyperkalemia and anemia may lead to electrolyte imbalances, such as hypocalcemia or hypokalemia.

In light of the patient's complex medical condition and goals of care, it is essential to continue close monitoring and management to prevent further complications and ensure a smooth transition to home hospice care.

   Has been on suppressive therapy with Augmentin and Bactrim, though
   wound is still poorly healing.
   - d/c abx as above
   - no further workup given goals of care
   # dCHF: Echo showed marked RV dysfunction with RV bowing into LV as
   above.  Prior echo in [**Month (only) 1148**] showed EF 65% with some old RV
   dysfunction, likely from prior PEs.  Also with pulmonary hypertension.
   - cautious fluid status managment as in very delicate balance
   # Multiple PEs: On coumadin, subtherapeutic, has h/o developing new PEs
   while on anticoagulation. Also has pulmonary hypertension [**2-28**] PEs, on
   viagra.
   - continue sildenafil 100mg tid
   - Heparin gtt given concern for PE
   # Anemia: 26 down from 33 two days ago. Possibly dilutional, no signs
   of bleeding though has guaiac pos stool in [**Location (un) 250**] ED.  Baseline Hct
   around 32 per report. Got 1 unit prbcs prior to transfer.
   - Guaiac all stools

   # Afib/flutter:  Coumadin held last night at pt was supratherapeutic
   - coumadin as above
   - continue digoxin as keeping patient rate controlled important for
   maintenance of BP and quality of life

   - no active treatment

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 78-year-old male with a history of PEs, pulmonary hypertension, COP, chronic knee infection, afib/flutter, and hypothyroidism, who was transferred to the ICU with shock and acute renal failure. The patient's condition has been stabilized, and the goal is to wean him off pressors and transition him to home for hospice care.

The patient's current vital signs are:

* Temperature: 36.2°C (97.2°F)
* Heart rate: 94 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 85/45 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 13 inspirations per minute (ipm)
* Oxygen saturation: 99%
* Heart rhythm: Atrial fibrillation

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 14.3
* Hematocrit: 33.7%
* Platelet count: 389
* Creatinine: 4.0 mg/dL
* Troponin: 0.06 ng/mL
* Lactic acid: 1.1 mmol/L
* Albumin: 3.6 g/dL
* LDH: 346 IU/L
* Calcium: 8.5 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 1.8 mg/dL
* Phosphate: 2.5 mg/dL

The patient's medical conditions include:

* Renal failure, acute
* Pain control, acute and chronic
* Hypotension, not shock
* Impaired skin integrity
* Cryptogenic organizing pneumonia
* Leukocytosis
* Right knee replacement with chronic infection
* Dilated cardiomyopathy
* Multiple pulmonary emboli
* Anemia
* Atrial fibrillation
* Electrocardiogram changes

The patient's current medications include:

* Sildenafil 100mg tid
* Prednisone 10mg po qd
* Bactrim 800mg po bid
* Augmentin 500mg po bid
* Coumadin 5mg po qd (held due to guaiac-positive stool)
* Digoxin 0.25mg po qd
* Proton pump inhibitor for stress ulcer prophylaxis

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Further deterioration of renal function
* Development of septic shock due to chronic knee infection
* Pulmonary embolism due to multiple pulmonary emboli
* Bleeding due to subtherapeutic coumadin levels
* Respiratory failure due to chronic obstructive pulmonary disease
* Cardiac arrest due to atrial fibrillation
* Infection due to compromised immune system

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continuing sildenafil 100mg tid to treat RV failure and maintain blood pressure
* Discontinuing IV antibiotics due to lack of clear infection
* Continuing PO Bactrim and Augmentin for chronic osteomyelitis suppression
* Discontinuing coumadin due to guaiac-positive stool and holding off on further workup
* Continuing prednisone 10mg po qd for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease
* Continuing digoxin 0.25mg po qd to maintain rate-controlled atrial fibrillation
* Monitoring for signs of bleeding due to subtherapeutic coumadin levels
* Monitoring for signs of respiratory failure due to chronic obstructive pulmonary disease
* Monitoring for signs of infection due to compromised immune system

Summary:

The patient is a 78-year-old male with a history of pulmonary hypertension, chronic knee infection, and hypothyroidism, who was transferred to the ICU with shock and acute renal failure. He has been diagnosed with chronic right ventricular failure, acute renal failure, and hyperkalemia, and has been treated with sildenafil, antibiotics, and steroids. He has been weaned off pressors and is being prepared for discharge to home with hospice care.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Renal Failure: The patient's acute renal failure is resolving, but he has chronic kidney disease and may continue to experience kidney function decline.
2. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure is satisfactory, but he has a history of hypotension and may experience further episodes.
3. Leukocytosis: The patient's leukocytosis is likely related to stress dose steroids and may resolve once the steroids are discontinued.
4. Cryptogenic Organizing Pneumonia: The patient has a history of steroid-dependent COP, and his current treatment plan includes continuing steroids and supplemental oxygen.
5. Right Knee Infection: The patient has a chronic right knee infection, which may continue to be a source of infection and septic shock.
6. Pulmonary Hypertension: The patient has pulmonary hypertension, which may continue to be a challenge in managing his blood pressure and oxygenation.
7. Anemia: The patient's anemia is likely related to chronic disease and may continue to be a challenge in managing his blood counts.
8. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient has atrial fibrillation, which may continue to be a challenge in managing his heart rate and rhythm.
9. Electrolyte Imbalance: The patient has an electrolyte imbalance, which may continue to be a challenge in managing his electrolyte levels.
10. Infection: The patient has a history of septic shock, and his current treatment plan includes antibiotics and antifungals to prevent further infection.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's kidney function and adjust his treatment plan as needed.
2. Continue to manage the patient's blood pressure and oxygenation, and adjust his treatment plan as needed.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's leukocytosis and adjust his treatment plan as needed.
4. Continue to manage the patient's COP and right knee infection, and adjust his treatment plan as needed.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's pulmonary hypertension and adjust his treatment plan as needed.
6. Continue to manage the patient's anemia and adjust his treatment plan as needed.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's atrial fibrillation and adjust his treatment plan as needed.
8. Continue to monitor the patient's electrolyte imbalance and adjust his treatment plan as needed.
9. Continue to monitor the patient for signs of infection and adjust his treatment plan as needed.

 goal to

   their home ready and then plan to d/c home tomorrow
   #  Goals of Care:  Family meeting held 3 days ago to discuss goals of
   care and prognosis.  Outcome of discussion is to attempt to wean
   patient off of pressors in effor to get him home for home hospice.
   Discussed medication regimen at length with team yesterdayand the
   following decisions were made:
   - continue sildenafil at 100mg tid to treat his RV failure, keep him
   off pressors and allow him to go home with hospice
   - will d/c iv antibiotics as has been no clear infection
   - continue one additional day of stress dose steroids, will then change
   to po regimen
   - will d/c coumadin given patient was guaiac (+) as OSH given risk of
   bleed and coumadin held overnight but continues to rise
   - Will not start Flolan as have been able to wean off pressor sand
   maintain blood pressures in 80
s just with sildenafil
   - PT consult to ensure that patient is able to stand and walk several
   steps as this goal is important for quality of life at home
   - palliative care following, appreciate recommendations - working to
   transition patient home to hospice.  Did not start Flolan as was able
   to wean off pressors and patient has remained cautiously stable for 24
   hours off pressor support.
   # Shock NOS:  Likely [**2-28**] to RV failure (chronic) and sub-optimally
   treated pulmonary hypertension as patient has not desired full
   treatment.  Patient with leukocytosis which is likely [**2-28**] to sstress
   dose steroids as not clinically systemically infected.  Currently off
   of neosynepherine.  Lasix challenge yesterday suggestive of slighty
   hypovolemia, also dropped pressures to 60's with AMS with fast
   recovery.  Patient with extremely poor forward flow and has little
   ability to maintain bp with changes in posture.
   - continue sildenafil 100mg tid

   that this is the amount of prednisone he is actually taking daily.  On
   2L NC at night when at home.
   - steroids as above
   - continue po Bactrim for ppx
   - Continue supplemental oxygen as needed
   # Leukocytosis: Stable, likely  [**2-28**] steroids
   - trend

   joint space.  This is possible source of infection for septic shock.
   Has been on suppressive therapy with Augmentin and Bactrim, though
   wound is still poorly healing.
   - d/c abx as above
   - no further workup given goals of care
   # dCHF: Echo showed marked RV dysfunction with RV bowing into LV as
   above.  Prior echo in [**Month (only) 1148**] showed EF 65% with some old RV
   dysfunction, likely from prior PEs.  Also with pulmonary hypertension.
   - cautious fluid status managment as in very delicate balance
   # Multiple PEs: On coumadin, subtherapeutic, has h/o developing new PEs
   while on anticoagulation. Also has pulmonary hypertension [**2-28**] PEs, on
   viagra.
   - continue sildenafil 100mg tid
   - Heparin gtt given concern for PE
   # Anemia: 26 down from 33 two days ago. Possibly dilutional, no signs
   of bleeding though has guaiac pos stool in [**Location (un) 250**] ED.  Baseline Hct
   around 32 per report. Got 1 unit prbcs prior to transfer.
   - Guaiac all stools

Summary:

The patient is a 78-year-old male with a history of pulmonary hypertension, chronic knee infection, afib/flutter, and hypothyroidism, who was transferred to the ICU with shock and acute renal failure. He has been weaned off pressors and is being managed with sildenafil 100mg tid to treat his RV failure. His goals of care are to transition him to home for hospice care, and a family meeting was held to discuss this plan.

The patient has several medical complications, including:

* Renal failure, acute (ARF)
* Hypotension (not shock)
* Impaired skin integrity
* Leukocytosis
* Hyperkalemia (resolved)
* Cryptogenic organizing pneumonia (steroid-dependent)
* R TKR with chronic infection
* dCHF (RV dysfunction)
* Multiple PEs (on coumadin, subtherapeutic)
* Anemia (dilutional, possibly)
* Afib/flutter
* ECG changes (S1Q3T3, ST depression)

The patient's medications include:

* Sildenafil 100mg tid
* Bactrim PO
* Coumadin (held overnight, but continues to rise)
* Stress dose steroids (d/c'd)
* Lasix (challenge yesterday)
* Flolan (not started)
* Augmentin and Bactrim (suppressive therapy for R TKR infection)
* Heparin gtt (given concern for PE)
* Digoxin (to keep patient rate controlled)

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Further deterioration of renal function
* Increased risk of bleeding due to subtherapeutic INR
* Development of septic shock due to chronic infection in the R TKR
* Respiratory failure due to impaired skin integrity
* Cardiac arrest due to RV dysfunction and afib/flutter
* Increased risk of PE due to chronic pulmonary hypertension and multiple PEs
* Anemia worsening due to dilutional anemia and chronic bleeding
* ECG changes worsening due to continued RV dysfunction and afib/flutter

The patient's care plan includes:

* Weaning off pressors and managing his blood pressure with sildenafil
* D/c'ing IV antibiotics and switching to PO antibiotics
* Continuing stress dose steroids and then switching to PO regimen
* Managing his fluid status carefully to avoid hypovolemia
* Monitoring his renal function and adjusting his medications accordingly
* Continuing palliative care and hospice services
* Monitoring his anemia and transfusing as necessary
* Continuing to monitor his ECG changes and adjusting his medications accordingly.

Summary:

The patient is a 24-hour-old male in the ICU with a history of chronic osteomyelitis, pulmonary hypertension, and recent bilateral total knee replacements. He has been experiencing respiratory failure, septic shock, and acute kidney injury. He is currently receiving sildenafil for right ventricular failure, stress dose steroids for chronic steroid dependency, and antibiotics for chronic osteomyelitis suppression. He has also been receiving digoxin for atrial fibrillation/flutter and coumadin for deep vein thrombosis prophylaxis.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.3°C, heart rate of 98 bpm, and blood pressure of 102/54 mmHg. His respiratory rate is 18 breaths per minute, and his oxygen saturation is 95%. He is receiving nasal cannula oxygen and has a tracheostomy tube in place.

The patient's laboratory results show leukocytosis, with a white blood cell count of 14.3 K/uL. His hemoglobin is 8.6 g/dL, and his platelet count is 389 K/uL. His blood urea nitrogen is 73 mg/dL, and his creatinine is 1.5 mg/dL. His troponin level is 0.06 ng/mL, and his lactic acid level is 1.1 mmol/L.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Right Ventricular Failure: The patient's right ventricular failure is likely to worsen if not managed properly. Sildenafil may help improve cardiac output, but further monitoring and treatment are necessary to prevent cardiac decompensation.
2. Leukocytosis: The patient's leukocytosis may be a sign of infection or inflammation, and further evaluation is necessary to determine the underlying cause. Stress dose steroids may be contributing to the leukocytosis, and a weaning trial may be necessary to determine the patient's steroid dependence.
3. Acute Kidney Injury: The patient's acute kidney injury is likely to worsen if not managed properly. Close monitoring of his creatinine and blood urea nitrogen levels is necessary to prevent further kidney damage.
4. Pulmonary Hypertension: The patient's pulmonary hypertension is likely to worsen if not managed properly. Further evaluation and treatment are necessary to prevent cardiac decompensation and improve oxygenation.
5. Chronic Osteomyelitis: The patient's chronic osteomyelitis is likely to worsen if not managed properly. Further evaluation and treatment are necessary to prevent further bone damage and improve wound healing.
6. Septic Shock: The patient's septic shock is likely to worsen if not managed properly. Close monitoring of his vital signs and laboratory results is necessary to prevent further organ damage and improve survival.
7. Atrial Fibrillation/Flutter: The patient's atrial fibrillation/flutter is likely to worsen if not managed properly. Further evaluation and treatment are necessary to prevent cardiac decompensation and improve rate control.
8. Electrolyte Imbalance: The patient's electrolyte imbalance is likely to worsen if not managed properly. Close monitoring of his electrolyte levels is necessary to prevent further imbalance and improve cardiac function.

   him at home. Family meeting has been set up for today, family will meet

   - family meeting today to discuss with family their concerns regarding

   # Shock NOS:  Likely [**2-28**] to RV failure (chronic) and sub-optimally

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 78-year-old male with a history of pulmonary hypertension, chronic knee infection, and other comorbidities, who was transferred to the ICU with shock and acute renal failure. The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: Tmax 36.7°C, HR 92 bpm, BP 113/62 mmHg, RR 17 breaths/min, SpO2 95%.
* Hemodynamic monitoring: The patient is off pressors, and his blood pressure is stable.
* Fluid balance: The patient has received 720 mL of IV fluids and has lost 485 mL of fluid, resulting in a negative balance of 150 mL.
* Respiratory support: The patient is receiving nasal cannula oxygen and has an SpO2 of 95%.
* Physical examination: The patient's peripheral vascular, skin, and neurologic examinations are not assessed due to lack of assessment.
* Lab results: The patient's WBC count is elevated, with a peak value of 18.7. His Hct is 33.7%, and his platelet count is 389. His Cr is 4.0, and his TropT is 0.06. Other lab results include elevated levels of ALT, AST, Alk Phos, and LDH.

The patient has been diagnosed with pulmonary hypertension, acute renal failure, and impaired aerobic capacity, balance, gait, muscle performance, transfers, ventilation, and skin integrity. He also has chronic knee infection, afib/flutter, and hypothyroidism.

The patient's goals of care are to be weaned off pressors and transitioned to home hospice. A family meeting has been scheduled to discuss the patient's discharge plan and address the family's concerns regarding home hospice.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Worsening of acute renal failure: The patient's Cr level is elevated, and his fluid balance is negative, which may indicate worsening of acute renal failure.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's SpO2 is 95%, and his RR is 17 breaths/min, which may indicate respiratory failure.
3. Infection: The patient has a chronic knee infection and is receiving suppressive therapy with Augmentin and Bactrim, which may not be effective in eradicating the infection.
4. Septic shock: The patient has leukocytosis, which may indicate an infection, and he has a history of chronic infection, which may lead to septic shock.
5. Cardiac complications: The patient has afib/flutter and hypothyroidism, which may increase his risk of cardiac complications.
6. Worsening of pulmonary hypertension: The patient's pulmonary hypertension may worsen if he is not treated aggressively.
7. Skin breakdown: The patient's skin integrity is impaired, which may lead to skin breakdown and pressure ulcers.
8. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's elevated levels of ALT, AST, and LDH may indicate gastrointestinal complications, such as pancreatitis or cholecystitis.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust his treatment plan accordingly to prevent these potential complications.

   This is a 78 year-old male with a history of PEs, pulmonary
   hypertension, COP, chronic knee infection, afib/flutter and
   hypothyroidism who is transferred from [**Hospital1 7**] [**Location (un) 250**] with shock and acute
   renal failure.   Family meeting held to address goals of care
 goal to
   wean patient off pressors in order to transition him to home for
   hospice.  Plan to d/c home with hospice today.
   #  Goals of Care:  Family meeting held 3 days ago to discuss goals of
   care and prognosis.  Outcome of discussion is to attempt to wean
   patient off of pressors in effor to get him home for home hospice.
   Discussed medication regimen at length with team yesterdayand the
   following decisions were made:
   - continue sildenafil at 100mg tid to treat his RV failure, keep him
   off pressors and allow him to go home with hospice
   - will d/c iv antibiotics as has been no clear infection
   - continue one additional day of stress dose steroids, will then change
   to prednisone 10mg po qd
   - will continue po bactrim and augmentin for chronic osteomyelitis
   suppression
   - will d/c coumadin given patient was guaiac (+) as OSH given risk of
   bleed  - patient to see Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 206**] in 2 week and INR will be drawn
   then/determination whether or not to restart
   - Will not start Flolan as have been able to wean off pressor sand
   maintain blood pressures in 80
s just with sildenafil
   - PT saw and patient was able to ambulate without getting dizzy and was
   able to walk pushing wheelchair
   - palliative care following, appreciate recommendations - working to
   transition patient home to hospice.
   # Shock NOS:  Likely [**2-28**] to RV failure (chronic) and sub-optimally
   treated pulmonary hypertension as patient has not desired full
   treatment.  Patient with leukocytosis which is likely [**2-28**] to sstress
   dose steroids as not clinically systemically infected.  Currently off
   of neosynepherine.  Lasix challenge yesterday suggestive of slighty
   hypovolemia, also dropped pressures to 60's with AMS with fast
   recovery.  Patient with extremely poor forward flow and has little
   ability to maintain bp with changes in posture.
   - continue sildenafil 100mg tid
   - Flolan as above
   - abx d/c'ed as above
   - palliative care as above
   # Hyperkalemia: Resolved
   # ARF: Resolving
   - Continue to trend
   - Follow UOP with goal >30 and goal to fully wean pressors
   - Renally dose meds
   - Avoid nephrotoxins
   - has low Ca, will hold off on further work up given goal of care is
   for patient to go home
   # Cryptogenic organizing pna: Steroid dependent since [**Month (only) 1148**], has been
   unable to wean below 10 mg daily.  Patient was not clear on admission
   that this is the amount of prednisone he is actually taking daily.  On
   2L NC at night when at home.
   - steroids as above
   - continue po Bactrim for ppx
   - Continue supplemental oxygen as needed
   # Leukocytosis: Stable, likely  [**2-28**] steroids
   # R TKR with chronic infection: Plain film showing free air within the
   joint space.  This is possible source of infection for septic shock.
   Has been on suppressive therapy with Augmentin and Bactrim, though
   wound is still poorly healing.
   - abx as above
   - no further workup given goals of care
   # dCHF: Echo showed marked RV dysfunction with RV bowing into LV as
   above.  Prior echo in [**Month (only) 1148**] showed EF 65% with some old RV
   dysfunction, likely from prior PEs.  Also with pulmonary hypertension.
   - cautious fluid status managment as in very delicate balance
   # Multiple PEs: On coumadin, subtherapeutic, has h/o developing new PEs
   while on anticoagulation. Also has pulmonary hypertension [**2-28**] PEs, on
   viagra.
   - continue sildenafil 100mg tid
   - holding anticoagulation as above
   # Anemia: 25 and stable. Possibly dilutional, no signs of bleeding
   though has guaiac pos stool in [**Location (un) 250**] ED.  Baseline Hct around 32 per
   report. Got 1 unit prbcs prior to transfer.
   - Guaiac all stools
   - Transfuse for <21
   # Afib/flutter:  Coumadin held last night at pt was supratherapeutic
   - coumadin as above
   - continue digoxin as keeping patient rate controlled important for
   maintenance of BP and quality of life
   - Continue to monitor on telemetry
   # ECG changes: He does have S1Q3T3, though not significantly changed
   from prior, patient has old RBBB. Troponin mildly elevated, and some ST
   depression in lateral precordial leads. No CP.
   - no active treatment
    # FEN: Regular diet as tolerated, encouraging po fliuds
   # Access: R femoral line, PIV

He was transferred from another hospital with shock and acute renal failure. The patient's condition is complex and requires careful management.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.7°C, heart rate of 92 bpm, and blood pressure of 113/62 mmHg. His respiratory rate is 17 breaths per minute, and his SpO2 is 95%. He is receiving oxygen therapy via nasal cannula.

The patient's laboratory results show leukocytosis, which is likely related to stress dose steroids. His renal function is improving, with a decreasing serum creatinine level. His electrolyte levels are stable, except for a low calcium level.

The patient's medical conditions include pulmonary hypertension, chronic kidney disease, and chronic osteomyelitis. He has a history of PEs and is on anticoagulation therapy. He is also taking medications for his chronic conditions, including sildenafil, prednisone, and augmentin.

The patient's goals of care are to be weaned off pressors and transitioned to home hospice. The team is working to achieve this goal by managing his medications, fluid status, and electrolyte levels. The patient is also receiving palliative care to address his pain and symptom management.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

9. Infection: The patient is at risk of developing an infection due to his chronic conditions and immunosuppressive therapy.
10. Respiratory failure: The patient is at risk of developing respiratory failure due to his chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COP) and pulmonary hypertension.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's health status as follows:

* The patient has primary pulmonary hypertension, which is likely contributing to his right ventricular (RV) failure.
* He has a history of chronic osteomyelitis, which is being managed with antibiotics.
* The patient has been experiencing leukocytosis, which is likely related to stress dose steroids.
* He has a history of septic shock, which has resolved, but he remains at risk for recurrent episodes.
* The patient has a diagnosis of cryptogenic organizing pneumonia, which is being managed with steroids.
* He has a history of chronic kidney disease (ARF) and is at risk for acute kidney injury.
* The patient has a diagnosis of anemia, which is likely dilutional.
* He has a history of atrial fibrillation/flutter and is being managed with digoxin.
* The patient has a history of pulmonary emboli (PEs) and is at risk for recurrent episodes.
* He is being treated with sildenafil to manage his RV failure and is being weaned off pressors.
* The patient's code status is DNR/DNI.

Potential medical complications that can arise based on the patient's current status include:

* Recurrent septic shock due to chronic osteomyelitis or other underlying infections.
* Acute kidney injury due to continued stress dose steroids or other underlying conditions.
* Worsening of RV failure and pulmonary hypertension, which can lead to cardiac arrest.
* Recurrent PEs, which can be life-threatening.
* Complications related to his chronic kidney disease, such as electrolyte imbalances or acidosis.
* Gastrointestinal bleeding due to his anemia or other underlying conditions.
* Respiratory failure due to his chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) or other underlying conditions.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust his treatment plan accordingly to prevent or manage these potential complications.
